thread.title: Rockwood holds off Austin-East
thread.title_full: Rockwood holds off Austin-East - PrepXtra Story

author: Patrick Givens
title: Rockwood holds off Austin-East
text:
Rockwood football coach John Webb knew a seventh straight playoff berth had to start with a win on Friday night.
His team certainly played like it.
The Tigers survived a furious fourth-quarter rally by Austin-East to win 33-26 at Sam Anderson Field.
"Our kids have done this all year long," Webb said. "We've lost a couple ball games, but we've not been out of any of them. We've played our butt off all year long."
When Will Warner hit Nathan Briley for a 66-yard touchdown pass with just over six minutes remaining, the game appeared all but decided. But Austin-East (6-2, 3-1 Region 2-2A) scored twice in the final five minutes on Darius Harper touchdown passes to Kajuan Hale-Ligon and Kashif Warren Jr. of 58 and 19 yards, respectively, to pull within six.
The Roadrunners recovered an onside kick with 1 minute, 6 seconds remaining, but Harper's fourth-down heave from near midfield fell incomplete.
"We were able to make some plays at the end and make it exciting," Austin-East coach Jeff Phillips said. "At the end of the day, Rockwood made one more play than we did."
The normally run-oriented Tigers threw a few wrinkles into their wing-T. Warner completed 10 of 15 passes for 209 yards and two touchdowns.
"We couldn't just run it all night long," Webb said. "Our tight end (Briley) has been a big target for us all year long and did an outstanding job tonight."
Isiah Jones accounted for three first-half touchdowns for the Tigers, scoring on runs of 9 and 35 yards and catching a 58-yard screen pass. The Tigers' senior rushed for 118 yards on 19 carries.
Rockwood (6-2, 3-1) led 19-14 at the half.
Trailing for most of the game, Harper passed for 491 yards and three touchdowns, adding another score on the ground. Warren caught nine passes for 198 yards.
"We gave ourselves a chance to host a (playoff) game later on in the year," said Webb. "We'll just have to see how it goes."
Patrick Givens is a freelance contributor.
